text:
It’s fall in North America, which means
four things: Flannel, football, fabulous foliage,
and pumpkin spice everything.

This flavor has been around for a while--mostly
in actual pumpkin pie--but it’s popularity

has exploded since the early 2000s, when Starbucks
hit the jackpot with its pumpkin spice latte.
But we may have hit peak pumpkin spice.

Market research firms have found that sales
of pumpkin spice products are slowing.

Meanwhile, maple-flavored foods and beverages
are seeing continued growth, particularly
when paired with savory flavors, like bacon.

As pumpkin spice becomes perhaps too commonplace,
maple is poised to take its spot as top fall

flavor, according to the foodservice research
firm Technomic.

Even major coffee chains are hedging their
fall flavor bets, adding new maple-flavored
drinks alongside their pumpkin spice ones.
So what are these flavors, exactly, and where do they come from?

Natural spices and other ingredients can’t
always be relied on for large-scale manufacturing
of flavored products.

So often, flavor chemists figure out the most
prominent flavor molecules in the real deal

using analytical tools like gas chromatography
and mass spectrometry.

They can then use those compounds as a starting
point to develop a production-ready flavoring.

Sometimes they can isolate flavor compounds
from natural spices by distilling or running
extractions and then use those in a product.

But when that’s not cost-effective, or when
human activities disrupt the supply of natural

spices and materials, it’s up to chemists
to synthesize the relevant flavor molecules,

or find convincing alternatives from other
sources.

We spoke with flavor chemist Susie Bautista
to learn more about the chemistry that goes
into distilling the essence of sweater weather.
Bautista: I love seasonal flavors.

I think the challenge for a flavor chemist
nowadays with the seasonal flavors, with any

flavor, is that a lot of our agricultural
supply of any of these wonderful beautiful
spices is they’re not as available.

If there’s a natural disaster, if there’s
political unrest, that changes the marketplace
too, so the flavor chemist has to step in.

Kerri: Take the artificial maple flavor for
example, which compared to trendy pumpkin
spice, is positively ancient.

Chemists commonly produce maple flavor using
seeds of an herb called fenugreek, which contain

the potent compound sotolone that’s responsible
for that mapley flavor.

They might round out the flavor with other
compounds, such as acetylpropionyl, which
adds a buttery flavor.

Butter is something many consumers associate
with maple, even if they don’t realize it.

Complementary flavors are essential for making
a flavoring palatable, which is especially

true of pumpkin spice, where pumpkin isn’t
even the focus.

Pumpkin spice flavor is meant to evoke a warm
slice of pumpkin pie, so chemists are looking

to replicate a spice mixture including cinnamon,
clove, nutmeg, and ginger.

Common stand-ins are cinnamic aldehydes for
cinnamon, eugenol for clove, sabinene for
nutmeg, and zingiberene for ginger.

As you might imagine, though, brands keep
a tight lid on their exact formulas.

And a flavor chemist’s job doesn’t end
with just identifying molecular targets.

Every flavor concoction must be tailored to
the type of product it’ll be used in.

A flavoring made for a latte might not work
the same in a muffin.

Bautista: If you’re doing a flavor for a
baked good, some of your concern is a lot

of your flavor will bake off, most of the
flavors are not heat stable.

Kerri: Beyond heat, flavors also have to stand up
to human scrutiny.

That means flavor chemists have to use a bit
of artistry in deciding which compounds make
the final cut.

Bautista: It’s scientifically based, making
flavors. You’ll look at assays and see

what chemists find in vanilla extracts, and
you’ll use that information, but you’ll

also just use your memory of what you smelled
and tasted and go, “I think that belongs there."

Thanks to flavor chemists like Bautista, you
can enjoy the experience of warm pumpkin pie

or a stack of syrup-drenched pancakes in basically
whatever form you’d like, whenever you’d like.

Maple may be having a moment, but no one’s
dumping
pumpkin just yet.

One thing seems certain: seasonal flavors
make money, and they’re here to stay.

Do you think maple can measure up to the popularity
of pumpkin spice?
Which flavor do you prefer?
Let us know in the comments.
